utterances: Paul, with about two minutes to go, talk to me about what Stanley has just brought up, the idea that there are so many imitators to the throne, as we talked about who wanted to be Richard Pryor but just didn't have the ability to do what he did.
Well, there's only one Richard Pryor.
There can't be two.
It's a done deal.
And what he's saying is true in a lot of areas.
Richard was brilliant at what he did and he gave a lot of love and he was very creative.
And it's--to me, it's like, you know, life is very strange.
Richard--his speech, his talking ability, Richard ended up where he wasn't talking anymore.
He talked with his eyes.
Whenever I'd go see him, he'd talked with his eyes.
He couldn't--it's like the same thing with Muhammad Ali.
These two people used their words and now they can't.
It's like something very strange about that to me, you know.
The world loved what they said and now they can't talk, you know.
And it's just weird to me.
I mean, that's why I said that Richard can't speak but I can speak, you know, 'cause I was right there.
Richard used to sleep on my living room floor when I first met him and drive my '52 Ford.
That's a true story.
He didn't even have a license.
He drove it for about three weeks.
And when--I told him to go to Berkeley.
When he went to Berkeley, California, we'd go up together--this is how much I love this man.
He was drinking all the way from Hennessy, drinking and driving, and we were singing all the way, all the old tunes.
That's how crazy I was, you know.
And that's a true story.
And then later on, Richard had a Rolls-Royce, a Corniche they call them, the real expensive one.
He came up to The Comedy Store in Hollywood, he drove it up.
And I said, `Richard, let me drive it up, let me park it.
He said, `I'm not letting you park my Rolls-Royce.
I said, `Well, you drove my '52 Ford for three weeks.
That was my Rolls-Royce.
He said, `Yeah, you're right,' and he let me drive it.
The world has truly lost some laughter and, as I said, often we use the word genius, but in this case, it is real.

Richard Pryor, dead at 65, but luckily those of us who were here at the time and shared the space and world with Richard Pryor were made a little happier at the time in the laughter that he brought to us.
Stanley Crouch, thank you very much for putting it in context socially for us.

And, Paul Mooney, thank you so much for joining us and sharing remembrances of one of your good friends and, again, you're as much of making Richard Pryor who he ultimately became as anyone, so we thank you so much.
Well, hey, it's the Lone Ranger and Tonto, it's Lucy and Ethel.
There's no separating Richard and I.
And we were there from the beginning and Richard did change a lot of things.
He really did.
He really did.
All right.
Paul Mooney, thank you very much.
Yeah, we go across quite often and we do a lot of shopping in Canada, but you know, I guess that's where that part is our - that our dollar doesn't go as far as it used to up there.
So, you're might - more likely to spend it at the Wal-Mart on this side of the border rather than the Wal-Mart on that side of the border?
Exactly.
Uh-huh.
So, how - is this something that you anticipated extending for a while?
Yeah.
From what we're hearing that they expect the dollar to stay here for quite a while and it has a lot to do with, I guess, how much U.S.
consumers buy goods from the outside, and the strong natural resource base of Canada.
Mm-hmm.
No, they don't expect it to change back the other way anytime soon.
So, as far as you're concerned, hats in the air.
Good news.
Very good.
All right.
Steve Banahan, good luck to you.
Okay, thank you.
Steve Banahan, sales manager of Moose River Lumber in Moose River, Maine.
That's one person's story about how the falling dollar affects him and his business.
What about you?
E-mail, again, is talk@npr.org.
And Jesus(ph) joins us on the line.
Jesus calling from Sacramento, California.
Hi, Neal.
Hi.
I'm one of the many Mexicans that works in California.
Mm-hmm.
And during the last few months, the money that I send back home seems to last them less and less and that's also due to the inflation in Mexico.
But to think is that now my family in Mexico is starting to save money, not in dollars but in euros.
Hmm.
And I have a couple of cousins that migrated to Montreal.
Really?
And not in the states, yeah.
Yeah.
That money you send back home, that's known - the technical term is remittances.
Yup.
And it's an important source of income for a lot of people in Mexico.
Well, I believe it's number one or two for the Mexican economy.
Mm-hmm.
So, the drop in the dollar is suddenly make all of those remittances worth a lot less.
Yes.
Oh, that's interesting.
And so, it's a real difference and enough of a difference that your family is starting to keep that bank account in euros.
Yes, they are.
They have been saving euros for about a year.
They only - we are only two people that have migrated to the States in my family.
And now I have two cousins that decided to move to Canada, and I have one that, is thinking about moving to Europe.
Hmm.
Well, thanks very much, Jesus and then good luck to you.
Thank you.
Appreciate it.
Joining us now is Mark Zandi, chief economist from MoodysEconomy.com.
He's with us from the studios at radio station WRTI in Philadelphia.
Mark, good to talk to you again.
It's good to be with you, Neal.
And those are little anecdotes from - well, both borders, I guess.
But generally, how is the fall of the dollar affecting the U.S.
economy?
Well, I think on net, it's been a positive.
And you got a sense of that from the businessperson in Maine.
It's a real boon to U.S.
business.
We are exporting a lot more now overseas, imports are coming in at a less rapid pace, and that's very positive for business.
Obviously, it's not very positive for consumers who are out buying imported goods and, thus, have to pay more for everything, from that Chilean wine that you mentioned to…
Mm-hmm.
…that handbag from Italy.
But on net, I think it's a positive, at least so far.
Mm-hmm.
Now, for most people in this country, does it really make much of a difference?
Yeah, it does.
We import 20, 25 percent of all the goods that we consume and that's up quite a bit over the last 10, 15, 20 years.
And so, increasingly, it is more important.
We all travel more globally than we used to.
You went to Rome and a lot of people traveled overseas and, you know, they're feeling the oh effects of that.
Mm-hmm.
I actually went to Venice, not to Rome, but that's okay.
Oh, I am sorry.
